articles.headline: 159,000 Jobs Lost in September, the Worst Month in Five Years
articles.snippet: The September figures are especially worrisome because the government conducted its survey before the credit crisis took a turn for the worse.
articles.abstract: The September figures are especially worrisome because the government conducted its survey before the credit crisis took a turn for the worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy lost 159,000 jobs in September, the worst month of retrenchment in five years, the government reported on Friday, amplifying fears that an already painful downturn had entered a more severe stage that could persist well into next year.

articles.headline: Where’s It All Going? Find Out Online
articles.snippet: Although you don’t have control of the stock market, you do have control over your personal budget.
articles.abstract: Although you don’t have control of the stock market, you do have control over your personal budget.
articles.lead_paragraph: So Congress finally passed the bill. Breathe a sigh of relief that all of that is behind us.

articles.headline: In Florida’s Economic Pain, Obama Gains Ground
articles.snippet: Voters across Florida said the debate over how to fix the credit crisis has pushed them from the Republican ticket.
articles.abstract: Voters across Florida said the debate over how to fix the credit crisis has pushed them from the Republican ticket.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW PORT RICHEY, Fla.  Jim Piccillo lost his job at a bank in August, applied for food stamps to support his two young daughters and swore off a life of loyalty to the Republican Party. He now volunteers here in Pasco County for Senator Barack Obama of Illinois.

articles.headline: Obama and ’60s Bomber: A Look Into Crossed Paths
articles.snippet: Records of a school reform project suggest Barack Obama has played down contact with Bill Ayers, a founder of the Weathermen, but they do not seem to have been close.
articles.abstract: Records of a school reform project suggest Barack Obama has played down contact with Bill Ayers, a founder of the Weathermen, but they do not seem to have been close.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  At a tumultuous meeting of anti-Vietnam War militants at the Chicago Coliseum in 1969, Bill Ayers helped found the radical Weathermen, launching a campaign of bombings that would target the Pentagon and United States Capitol.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Uses $61 Billion of Fed Loan
articles.snippet: The insurer said it had already drawn down $61 billion of its $85 billion emergency bridge loan, a move that startled credit ratings agencies.
articles.abstract: The insurer said it had already drawn down $61 billion of its $85 billion emergency bridge loan, a move that startled credit ratings agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group said on Friday that it had already drawn down $61 billion of the $85 billion emergency bridge loan it received from the Federal Reserve two weeks ago, an announcement that startled credit ratings agencies.

articles.headline: They’re Pinching Hundred-Dollar Bills
articles.snippet: The turmoil on Wall Street has not only taken down once-solid companies, it has cut into the wealth of some Americans whose fortunes were tied to those companies.
articles.abstract: The turmoil on Wall Street has not only taken down once-solid companies, it has cut into the wealth of some Americans whose fortunes were tied to those companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The jet set, too, feels the pain.

articles.headline: Citi, Jilted in Wachovia Deal, Ponders Lawsuit
articles.snippet: Citigroup all but declared war Friday after Wachovia, the bank it rescued just four days ago, announced that it was scuttling the deal to form a new one with Wells Fargo, Citigroup’s rival.
articles.abstract: Citigroup all but declared war Friday after Wachovia, the bank it rescued just four days ago, announced that it was scuttling the deal to form a new one with Wells Fargo, Citigroup’s rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hell hath no fury like a white knight spurned.

articles.headline: Anxiety on Economy Wins Out
articles.snippet: As the fear sweeping Wall Street finally reached Congress, House Democrats passed the $700 billion bailout bill in a resounding vote.
articles.abstract: As the fear sweeping Wall Street finally reached Congress, House Democrats passed the $700 billion bailout bill in a resounding vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: The thing that surprised me most, after the $700 billion bailout bill finally passed, was that Barney Frank never cracked a smile.

articles.headline: For Treasury Dept., Now Comes Hard Part of Bailout
articles.snippet: The Treasury has barely a month to create a massive asset management firm and put a dollar value on assets that no one wants.
articles.abstract: The Treasury has barely a month to create a massive asset management firm and put a dollar value on assets that no one wants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It will be one of the world’s largest asset management firms with an impressive $700 billion war chest. Nothing short of the global economy depends on its success. And the Treasury Department has barely a month to get it up and running.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: Reports Link Karzai’s Brother to Afghanistan Heroin Trade
articles.snippet: Assertions that the Afghan president’s brother is linked to the heroin trade have deeply worried American officials.
articles.abstract: Assertions that the Afghan president’s brother is linked to the heroin trade have deeply worried American officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Afghan security forces found an enormous cache of heroin hidden beneath concrete blocks in a tractor-trailer outside Kandahar in 2004, the local Afghan commander quickly impounded the truck and notified his boss.

articles.headline: Despite Ruling, Detainee Cases Facing Delays
articles.snippet: Months after a Supreme Court ruling, none of the habeas corpus cases of Guantánamo detainees have been resolved.
articles.abstract: Months after a Supreme Court ruling, none of the habeas corpus cases of Guantánamo detainees have been resolved.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court ruled in June that detainees at Guantánamo had the right to challenge their detention in federal court, the justices said that after more than six years of legal wrangling the prisoners should have their cases heard quickly because “the costs of delay can no longer be borne by those who are held in custody.”

articles.headline: Pressured to Take More Risk, Fannie Reached Tipping Point
articles.snippet: A decision, made under pressure from Congress and investors, to steer Fannie Mae into dangerous corners of the mortgage market proved to be disastrous.
articles.abstract: A decision, made under pressure from Congress and investors, to steer Fannie Mae into dangerous corners of the mortgage market proved to be disastrous.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Almost no one expected what was coming. It’s not fair to blame us for not predicting the unthinkable.“ Daniel H. Mudd, former chief executive, Fannie Mae

articles.headline: End of an Era on Wall Street: Goodbye to All That
articles.snippet: Historians, economists and pundits are busily debating the end of Wall Street’s era of big spending and high living.
articles.abstract: Historians, economists and pundits are busily debating the end of Wall Street’s era of big spending and high living.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST before midnight 10 days ago, as a financial whirlwind tore through Wall Street, someone filched a 75-pound bronze bust of Harry Poulakakos from the vestibule of his landmark saloon on Hanover Square in Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: At JetBlue, Growing Up Is Hard to Do
articles.snippet: Ever since the snowstorm debacle last year, JetBlue has been on a reinvention drive amid the biggest crisis airlines have faced in years.
articles.abstract: Ever since the snowstorm debacle last year, JetBlue has been on a reinvention drive amid the biggest crisis airlines have faced in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: JETBLUE AIRWAYS was the darling of the airline industry until Valentine’s Day, 2007. And life for the carrier hasn’t been the same since.

articles.headline: Taking 450 Teenagers Under Her Wing
articles.snippet: A guidance counselor at Healdsburg High School in California focuses on what comes after high school.
articles.abstract: A guidance counselor at Healdsburg High School in California focuses on what comes after high school.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’M a guidance counselor at Healdsburg High School, a public school in Sonoma County, Calif. The job is challenging, but it always presents something new. I love learning and I enjoy working with teenagers. The fact that I can help them move on to the next step in their lives I find very rewarding.

articles.headline: Economic Unrest Shifts Electoral Battlegrounds
articles.snippet: Barack Obama is gaining force, while John McCain is scaling back his efforts to capture Democratic states.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama is gaining force, while John McCain is scaling back his efforts to capture Democratic states.
articles.lead_paragraph: The turmoil on Wall Street and the weakening economy are changing the contours of the presidential campaign map, giving new force to Senator Barack Obama’s ambitious strategy to make incursions into Republican territory, while leading Senator John McCain to scale back his efforts to capture Democratic states.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Media Pave the Way to 3rd Term for Bloomberg
articles.snippet: Before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his controversial run for another term, he locked up support of the editorial pages of three city newspapers.
articles.abstract: Before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his controversial run for another term, he locked up support of the editorial pages of three city newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor of New York, stepped to the microphone last Thursday at City Hall to announce that he would probably run for a third term even though he was limited by law to two terms, he was framed by a huge portrait of Alexander Hamilton, the New York delegate to the Constitutional Convention.

articles.headline: Google Deal With Yahoo Draws More Opposition
articles.snippet: Resentment and fear of Google’s power is growing among some of the biggest players in the advertising industry.
articles.abstract: Resentment and fear of Google’s power is growing among some of the biggest players in the advertising industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s antitrust investigation of the advertising partnership between Google and Yahoo has revealed the growing resentment and fear of Google’s power among some of the biggest players in the advertising industry  the very customers that Google needs to keep expanding its business.

articles.headline: Like J.P. Morgan, Warren E. Buffett Braves a Crisis
articles.snippet: Comparing the two men in periods of market turmoil reveals how much some things have changed over the years and how others have not.
articles.abstract: Comparing the two men in periods of market turmoil reveals how much some things have changed over the years and how others have not.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the midst of a financial crisis, a towering figure of American business steps forward with his reputation and financial resources for public good and personal gain.

articles.headline: Full of Doubts, U.S. Shoppers Cut Spending
articles.snippet: Consumers are pulling back on their spending, all but guaranteeing that the economic situation will get worse.
articles.abstract: Consumers are pulling back on their spending, all but guaranteeing that the economic situation will get worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cowed by the financial crisis, American consumers are pulling back on their spending, all but guaranteeing that the economic situation will get worse before it gets better.
articles.byline: By Louis Uchitelle, Andrew Martin and Stephanie Rosenbloom

articles.headline: Post-Apartheid South Africa Enters Anxious Era
articles.snippet: South Africa is struggling with high crime, xenophobic violence, and an economic downturn.
articles.abstract: South Africa is struggling with high crime, xenophobic violence, and an economic downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: DIEPSLOOT, South Africa  A dusty maze of concrete, sheet metal and scrap wood, Diepsloot is like so many of the enormous settlements around Johannesburg, mile after mile of feebly assembled shacks, the impromptu patchwork of the poor, the extremely poor and the hopelessly poor.

articles.headline: Rivals Present Sharp Divide on Iraq Goals
articles.snippet: At the heart of the dispute between the 2008 candidates is Barack Obama’s timeline for withdrawing U.S. troops.
articles.abstract: At the heart of the dispute between the 2008 candidates is Barack Obama’s timeline for withdrawing U.S. troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  One of the most pressing questions Senator Barack Obama or Senator John McCain would confront if elected president is how to build on the security gains in Iraq at a time when troop levels have begun to drop.

articles.headline: Financial Crises Spread in Europe
articles.snippet: The growing crisis has underlined the difficulty of taking concerted action in Europe because its economies are far more integrated than its governing structures.
articles.abstract: The growing crisis has underlined the difficulty of taking concerted action in Europe because its economies are far more integrated than its governing structures.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Carter Dougherty, Nelson Schwartz and Floyd Norris and written by Mr. Norris.
articles.byline: By CARTER DOUGHERTY, NELSON SCHWARTZ and FLOYD NORRIS

articles.headline: The Road to Lehman’s Failure Was Littered With Lost Chances
articles.snippet: Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive, will discuss these lost opportunities in a Congressional hearing on Monday.
articles.abstract: Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive, will discuss these lost opportunities in a Congressional hearing on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard S. Fuld Jr. was under siege in mid-July. His renowned investment bank, Lehman Brothers, was barraged with questions about whether the expanding credit crisis would engulf the bank and wipe out investors.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Ben White

articles.headline: Countrywide to Set Aside $8.4 Billion in Loan Aid
articles.snippet: As part of a settlement with officials in 11 states, Countrywide has agreed to the largest program ever to modify home loans.
articles.abstract: As part of a settlement with officials in 11 states, Countrywide has agreed to the largest program ever to modify home loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Countrywide Financial has agreed to the largest program ever to modify home loans, as part of a settlement with officials in 11 states, just days after the federal government adopted a giant financial rescue package without any relief for distressed homeowners.

articles.headline: Weekend Legal Frenzy Between Citigroup and Wells Fargo for Wachovia
articles.snippet: The epic battle engulfed two courts and pitted a cast of bankers, lawyers and federal regulators against one another.
articles.abstract: The epic battle engulfed two courts and pitted a cast of bankers, lawyers and federal regulators against one another.
articles.lead_paragraph: A showdown between two of the nation’s largest banks over the Wachovia Corporation grew into a widening battle involving two courts and a cast including Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke and an army of bankers, lawyers and other regulators trying to resolve the fate Sunday of one of the biggest prizes to emerge from the credit crisis.

articles.headline: Fed Considers Plan to Buy Companies’ Unsecured Debt
articles.snippet: As stocks spiraled lower around the world, the Federal Reserve considered a radical plan to jump-start the ailing financial system.
articles.abstract: As stocks spiraled lower around the world, the Federal Reserve considered a radical plan to jump-start the ailing financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve announced a radical new plan on Tuesday to jump-start the engine of the financial system.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: A United Image, Battered by Reality
articles.snippet: European governments pledged to safeguard bank deposits in a bid to stem financial panic, but they stopped short of a coordinated strategy.
articles.abstract: European governments pledged to safeguard bank deposits in a bid to stem financial panic, but they stopped short of a coordinated strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  European governments pledged Monday to safeguard bank deposits in a bid to stem financial panic, but they stopped short of a coordinated strategy to break the grip of a credit crisis that now threatens to set off a protracted recession across the Continent, sending markets tumbling on both sides of the Atlantic.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Carter Dougherty

articles.headline: Lehman Managers Portrayed as Irresponsible
articles.snippet: As Lehman pleaded for a bailout, it approved millions for its executives, a Congressional committee was told.
articles.abstract: As Lehman pleaded for a bailout, it approved millions for its executives, a Congressional committee was told.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Richard S. Fuld Jr. blamed the news media. He blamed the short-sellers. He blamed the government, as well as what he characterized as an “extraordinary run on the bank.”
articles.byline: By Bernie Becker and Ben White
